E6F54405FEF949D1BBBECD467192E365.description: Discuss how the uses of science can have a global environmental impact.

96FA942727DA438F9F37A075CD7BBAB1.description: Describe how people develop and use scientific understanding, as individuals and through collaboration, e.g. through peer-review.

9E1F463B175844369BF1C8827BA713AF.description: Evaluate issues which involve and/or require scientific understanding.

E17E7ED1264E4E67B194BF7FA2792998.description: Describe how science is applied across societies and industries, and in research.

41546A915DBB4B27BB52ACFD3601339C.description: Discuss how scientific knowledge is developed through collective understanding and scrutiny over time.

E7BDAF075DEB42F2B40860FBCF4FEA3D.description: Explain how solar and lunar eclipses happen.

6C4B7676C7F046C78837968471836637.description: Describe tidal forces on Earth as a consequence of the gravitational attraction between the Earth, Moon and Sun.

A81A030F721D48C18D620C8772EDECC3.description: Know that gravity is the force that holds components of the Solar System in orbit around the Sun.

BF285EC127DC42279F867690C01F7AF7.description: Describe how planets form from dust and gas, which are pulled together by gravity.

5450A2FAF72849E6B9EC612395A7621D.description: Describe the water cycle (limited to evaporation, condensation, precipitation, water run-off, open water and groundwater).

56204BCF0BA6468293DEBB4A769812AD.description: Know that clean, dry air contains 78% nitrogen, 21% oxygen and small amounts of carbon dioxide and other gases, and this composition can change because of pollution and natural emissions.

76C85353AD604A7DA1E6D7CDBDC00620.description: Describe how earthquakes, volcanoes and fold mountains occur near the boundaries of tectonic plates.

3320C0C4DA6944B5A148CEF86390058E.description: Describe the model of plate tectonics, in which a solid outer layer (made up of the crust and uppermost mantle) moves because of flow lower in the mantle.

5483AD9B604A4DD0A9C324FB5EB544E7.description: Use diagrams and conventional symbols to represent, make and compare circuits that include cells, switches, lamps, buzzers and ammeters.

77AE02F9E69F402F84CE47A4A12B6527.description: Describe how adding components into a series circuit can affect the current (limited to addition of cells and lamps).

EAB8B2E556D24DC8AE0FD459B68E3242.description: Know how to measure the current in series circuits.

9993BC616C2146F8865AD4E924727C85.description: Describe electrical conductors as substances that allow electron flow and electrical insulators as substances that inhibit electron flow.

1BF81F561C02402194A8DE377EFD3CEB.description: Use a simple model to describe electricity as a flow of electrons around a circuit.

DEB8B45D6BA047CD961C2E564FD64210.description: Explain echoes in terms of the reflection of sound waves.

797079CF7CDA4299A48DD31CC2DCA8FD.description: Describe the vibration of particles in a sound wave and explain why sound does not travel in a vacuum.

470BEB7CE947473FB968A7739C57DDAF.description: Understand that there is no air resistance to oppose movement in a vacuum.

4B8F3548EB5A4A83B5E52D7718F9A862.description: Describe gravity as a force of attraction between any two objects and describe how the size of the force is related to the masses of the objects.

8BAB37E240D0455999268D4B8F3702D8.description: Know that energy tends to dissipate and in doing so it becomes less useful.

15AA32BF96084DE2B50DDBB72110F1C6.description: Describe changes in energy that are a result of an event or process.

9B82B55C170A45F7AA8C6F022A950720.description: Describe neutralisation reactions in terms of change of pH.

D9D68510E5E347FAB4F329DB57DF54A4.description: Use the particle model to describe chemical reactions.

0E66DE4D4D5743DBBC68511B929B520F.description: Explain why a precipitate forms, in terms of a chemical reaction between soluble reactants forming at least one insoluble product.

8C68A71FA12E45549F218F0568B3392B.description: Identify whether a chemical reaction has taken place through observations of the loss of reactants and/or the formation of products which have different properties to the reactants (including evolving a gas, formation of a precipitate or change of colour).

6D4BC08058944EB685547EC738B25986.description: Use the particle model to explain the difference in hardness between pure metals and their alloys.

16D55B93682B4003B1F76BB38592C5B5.description: Understand that alloys are mixtures that have different chemical and physical properties from the constituent substances.

2229AC7E81F94EA1A3E0FA18F0743D2E.description: Describe common differences between metals and non-metals, referring to their physical properties.

547F60FFEE7B46E4BC134899F8F275CC.description: Use tests to identify hydrogen, carbon dioxide and oxygen gases.

8CBDADCD840B4E93AAB0CF872A977314.description: Use indicators (including Universal Indicator and litmus) to distinguish between acidic, alkaline and neutral solutions.

D42EB4BE2F004A18A01A72DF85026CC6.description: Understand that the acidity or alkalinity of a substance is a chemical property and is measured by pH.

AD3D6E984CFE4A09ABFA55D1224AFF3A.description: Understand that all substances have chemical properties and physical properties.

813B4F80424045B1AE749B425E9B2B4D.description: Use the particle model to represent elements, compounds and mixtures.

0C65425782B14033929608427AB3B2D9.description: Describe the three states of matter as solid, liquid and gas in terms of the arrangement, separation and motion of particles.

9514B696D8354A2295E385263269A46B.description: Describe a vacuum as a space devoid of matter.

8E764F91C1964366A12D59926BBAE4BF.description: Describe the differences between elements, compounds and mixtures, including alloys as an example of a mixture.

5480ED2B291642CBAECA3ED883022835.description: Know metals and non-metals as the two main groupings of elements.

B8A3CF8C4E6B4DDFA27DE234A85CD935.description: Know that the Periodic Table presents the known elements in an order.

300C5EEBDF7D4622873CBC09D0EC7DDC.description: Understand that all matter is made of atoms, with each different type of atom being a different element.

27299225540E4CC99900F8646A4763D2.description: Construct and interpret food chains and webs which include microorganisms as decomposers.

44C1AAC355C64185A811477D5F6B3CFF.description: Know and describe the ecological role some microorganisms have as decomposers.

2014E96BB8154B108E934508FDA2410B.description: Use and construct dichotomous keys to classify species and groups of related organisms.

D0091C27EDDA45B580AAF720EDFD9EA1.description: Describe a species as a group of organisms that can reproduce to produce fertile offspring.

81DC188424214E418E25FD09A4D5CB86.description: Discuss reasons for classifying viruses as living or non-living.

A6F1E178A34A4538B72A58A54085FF6C.description: Describe the seven characteristics of living organisms.

89EC111BEA2945EE8F164B6D79B20899.description: Understand that cells can be grouped together to form tissues, organs and organ systems.

7FFB18A210D74D97BB72E5C585D17D40.description: Describe the similarities and differences between the structures of plant and animal cells.

D0F16FD6861A42C7B56C6F622572C1CE.description: Explain how the structures of some specialised cells are related to their functions (including red blood cells, neurones, ciliated cells, root hair cells and palisade cells).

2A295F8C5341401F9FBC345CA2D56A16.description: Identify and describe the functions of cell structures (limited to cell membrane, cytoplasm, nucleus, cell wall, chloroplast, mitochondria and sap vacuole).

B7E74B3BC3DA44ABABC044F547646903.description: Understand that all organisms are made of cells and microorganisms are typically single celled.

AE88AD0778FE4277A2E1CA76CBB7BB7E.description: Present and interpret observations and measurements appropriately.

C029EEA6E9BE43198D5DFCF64848A83B.description: Evaluate experiments and investigations, and suggest improvements, explaining any proposed changes.

0BBB7A149B9049F3A0F24E7B4CA876A2.description: Make conclusions by interpreting results and explain the limitations of the conclusions.

D7C76B418BA14F2B808570DFCC04C51F.description: Describe trends and patterns in results, including identifying any anomalous results.

18E0FEED0E894C728F88388CE92E4DBF.description: Describe the accuracy of predictions, based on results, and suggest why they were or were not accurate.

A998F562C81A42D18071B12BA213C27E.description: Scientific enquiry: analysis, evaluation and conclusions

33BFF7B484384893B28E934ACD5E8F1E.description: Collect and record sufficient observations and/or measurements in an appropriate form.

B79E6B13FA7741A593876B3C146CBA7D.description: Evaluate a range of secondary information sources for their relevance and know that some sources may be biased.

0BB7336EB77F4443B5700430153D56A1.description: Take appropriately accurate and precise measurements, explaining why accuracy and precision are important.

96FBFA2B25D44019B86C987C1D29B83C.description: Evaluate whether measurements and observations have been repeated sufficiently to be reliable.

63F537F69E484FB9B5D8AEA53A69E2E1.description: Decide what equipment is required to carry out an investigation or experiment and use it appropriately.

2B9CE82034A246F683C71F0A7F5BB4D1.description: Sort, group and classify phenomena, objects, materials and organisms through testing, observation, using secondary information, and making and using keys.

A92158492247424BA4DD7BBF06E2B8DC.description: Know the meaning of hazard symbols, and consider them when planning practical work.

F6C9CF4BB61041E9A4AE2E7372ABB031.description: Plan a range of investigations of different types, while considering variables appropriately, and recognise that not all investigations can be fair tests.

CB27D6395FEC4AAE8FB5A698A3C94A18.description: Make predictions of likely outcomes for a scientific enquiry based on scientific knowledge and understanding.

F72E1E53EC094DAFA433A3231540ADC0.description: Describe how scientific hypotheses can be supported or contradicted by evidence from an enquiry.

D6FD94A3F2C04E979A339B76710E7AA8.description: Identify whether a given hypothesis is testable.

A68BBCC5F2A0441DAC463D8639820846.description: Use symbols and formulae to represent scientific ideas.

DE36596F2C33481AA2BE46BA1BA1CFC1.description: Describe the strengths and limitations of a model.
